verses.verse: Then Job<WH347> answered<WH6030> and said,<WH559>
I know<WH3045> it is so<WH3651> of a truth:<WH551> but how<WH4100> should man<WH582> be just<WH6663> with God?<WH410>
If<WH518> he will contend<WH7378> with him, he cannot<WH3808> answer<WH6030> him one<WH259> of a thousand.<WH505>
He is wise<WH2450> in heart,<WH3824> and mighty<WH533> in strength:<WH3581> who<WH4310> has hardened<WH7185> himself against<WH413> him, and has prospered?<WH7999>
Which removes<WH6275> the mountains,<WH2022> and they know<WH3045> not: which<WH834> overturns<WH2015> them in his anger.<WH639>
Which shakes<WH7264> the earth<WH776> out of her place,<WH4725> and the pillars<WH5982> thereof tremble.<WH6426>
Which commands<WH559> the sun,<WH2775> and it rises<WH2224> not; and seals<WH2856> up the stars.<WH3556>
Which alone<WH905> spreads<WH5186> out the heavens,<WH8064> and treads<WH1869> on the waves<WH1116> of the sea.<WH3220>
Which makes<WH6213> Arcturus,<WH5906> Orion,<WH3685> and Pleiades,<WH3598> and the chambers<WH2315> of the south.<WH8486>
Which does<WH6213> great<WH1419> things past<WH369> finding<WH2714> out; yes, and wonders<WH6381> without<WH5704> <WH369> number.<WH4557>
See,<WH2005> he goes<WH5674> by me, and I see<WH7200> him not: he passes<WH2498> on also, but I perceive<WH995> him not.
Behold,<WH2005> he takes<WH2862> away,<WH2862> who<WH4310> can hinder<WH7725> him? who<WH4310> will say<WH559> to him, What<WH4100> do<WH6213> you?
If God<WH433> will not withdraw<WH7725> his anger,<WH639> the proud<WH7293> helpers<WH5826> do stoop<WH7817> under<WH8478> him.
How<WH637> much<WH637> <WH3588> less shall I answer<WH6030> him, and choose<WH977> out my words<WH1697> to reason with him?
Whom,<WH834> though<WH518> I were righteous,<WH6663> yet would I not answer,<WH6030> but I would make supplication<WH2603> to my judge.<WH8199>
If<WH518> I had called,<WH7121> and he had answered<WH6030> me; yet would I not believe<WH539> that he had listened<WH238> to my voice.<WH6963>
For he breaks<WH7779> me with a tempest,<WH8183> and multiplies<WH7235> my wounds<WH6482> without<WH2600> cause.<WH2600>
He will not suffer<WH5414> me to take my breath,<WH7307> but fills<WH7646> me with bitterness.<WH4472>
If<WH518> I speak of strength,<WH3581> see,<WH2009> he is strong:<WH533> and if<WH518> of judgment,<WH4941> who<WH4310> shall set<WH3259> me a time to plead?
If<WH518> I justify<WH6663> myself, my own mouth<WH6310> shall condemn<WH7561> me: if I say, I am perfect,<WH8535> it shall also prove me perverse.<WH6140>
Though I were perfect,<WH8535> yet would I not know<WH3045> my soul:<WH5315> I would despise<WH3988> my life.<WH2416>
This<WH1931> is one<WH259> thing, therefore<WH5921> <WH3651> I said<WH559> it, He destroys<WH3615> the perfect<WH8535> and the wicked.<WH7563>
If<WH518> the whip<WH7752> slay<WH4191> suddenly,<WH6597> he will laugh<WH3932> at the trial<WH4531> of the innocent.<WH5355>
The earth<WH776> is given<WH5414> into the hand<WH3027> of the wicked:<WH7563> he covers<WH4374> the faces<WH6440> of the judges<WH8199> thereof; if<WH518> not, where,<WH645> and who<WH4310> is he?
Now my days<WH3117> are swifter<WH7043> than<WH4480> a post:<WH7323> they flee<WH1272> away, they see<WH7200> no<WH3808> good.<WH2896>
They are passed<WH2498> away as the swift<WH16> ships:<WH591> as the eagle<WH5404> that hastens<WH2907> to the prey.<WH400>
If<WH518> I say,<WH559> I will forget<WH7911> my complaint,<WH7879> I will leave<WH5800> off my heaviness,<WH6440> and comfort<WH1082> myself:
I am afraid<WH3025> of all<WH3605> my sorrows,<WH6094> I know<WH3045> that you will not hold me innocent.<WH5352>
If I be wicked,<WH7561> why<WH4100> then labor<WH3021> I in vain?<WH1892>
If<WH518> I wash<WH7364> myself with snow<WH7950> water,<WH7950> and make my hands<WH3709> never<WH1253> so clean;<WH2141>
Yet<WH227> shall you plunge<WH2881> me in the ditch,<WH7845> and my own clothes<WH8008> shall abhor<WH8581> me.
For he is not a man,<WH376> as I am, that I should answer<WH6030> him, and we should come<WH935> together<WH3162> in judgment.<WH4941>
Neither<WH3808> is there any judge<WH3198> between<WH996> us, that might lay<WH7896> his hand<WH3027> on us both.<WH8147>
Let him take<WH5493> his rod<WH7626> away<WH5493> from me, and let not his fear<WH367> terrify<WH1204> me:
Then would I speak,<WH1696> and not fear<WH3372> him; but it is not so<WH3651> with me.
